entry.title: Flood Watch issued September 18 at 3:28AM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: .Low pressure moving northward off the Mid Atlantic Coast will move into the Gulf of Maine tonight. entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 17 at 8:53PM PDT until September 18 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINDY AND DRY CONDITIONS THROUGH MONDAY... .A pair of dry cold fronts will sweep through the region today and Monday, making for breezy conditions during the afternoon and evening hours each day. Winds are expected to be at their strongest on Monday, with RHs remaining at critical levels despite cooler conditions prevailing behind today`s front.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Columbia Basin of Oregon

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 18 at 2:58AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Patchy, Locally Dense, Fog Possible This Morning... Patchy fog, locally dense, especially near bodies of water and other usual fog prone locations, has and will continue to develop as early morning hours progress today. entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 18 at 2:46AM PDT until September 18 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...MORE DRY AND WINDY CONDITIONS MONDAY... .A strong dry cold front on Monday will produce more gusty winds and low relative humidity. ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TODAY TO 8 PM PDT THIS EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR MUCH OF CENTRAL AND EASTERN WASHINGTON...

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 18 at 2:29AM PDT until September 19 at 2:00PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM PDT THIS MORNING THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Sneaker waves possible. * WHERE...In Oregon, North Oregon Coast and Central Oregon Coast. In Washington, South Washington Coast. * WHEN...From 8 AM PDT this morning through Tuesday afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Washington Coast

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 17 at 8:53PM PDT until September 18 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINDY AND DRY CONDITIONS THROUGH MONDAY... .A pair of dry cold fronts will sweep through the region today and Monday, making for breezy conditions during the afternoon and evening hours each day. Winds are expected to be at their strongest on Monday, with RHs remaining at critical levels despite cooler conditions prevailing behind today`s front.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kittitas Valley; Lower Columbia Basin

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 18 at 4:32AM CDT until September 18 at 10:00PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Dangerous swimming conditions are expected along the Lake Superior shoreline due to high wave action and strong rip currents. * WHERE...Minnesota Park Point and Wisconsin Point Beaches. * WHEN...Through this evening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Douglas

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 18 at 1:33AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FOG AND PATCHY FROST EARLY THIS MORNING... Areas of fog, some dense, and patchy fog will develop tonight across portions of northwest Wisconsin. The visibility in fog may drop to a half mile or less creating hazardous driving conditions in spots. The frost will be more likely inland from Lake Superior.
